data.title: Flipped tiles in hexamap demo are broken
data.body: Likely since #3204 which caused some offset for vertically flipped tiles. As I understand it #3204 fixed a previously wrong behaviour, so now we need to rethink the hexamap demo to show how to make hexagonal tilesets that can still be flipped properly.

data.title: Remove trailing spaces
data.body:
Follow-up on #3928.

I used:

```
find . -type f \( -name "*\.py" -o -name "SCsub" -o -name "SConstruct" -o -name "*\.inc" \) -a \( ! -path "./drivers/*" \) -print0 | xargs -0 -I {} sed -i'' -e's/[[:space:]]*$//' "{}"
find . -type f \( -name "*\.mm" -o -name "*\.json" -o -name "*\.js" -o -name "*\.css" \) -a \( ! -path "./drivers/*" \) -print0 | xargs -0 -I {} sed -i'' -e's/[[:space:]]*$//' "{}"
```

data.title: Suggestion: Separate help pages from scripts
data.body: On the scripts page, in the list of scripts, please separate scripts from help pages.  I can have a LOT more of the help pages open than scripts and then it gets tedious to find the script I actually need. It would be cool to have 2 tabs at the top of this page, or the top of the list panel, Scripts and Help.  Something to help organize.

data.title: "Toggle comment" undesirable behaviour
data.body:
Take any 3 consecutive lines of code (1, 2, & 3)
Place cursor at start of line 1.
Use keyboard (Shift Down-arrow) or mouse (click & drag down) to highlight lines 1 & 2 fully. Cursor is now at beginning of line 3.
Press Ctrl-K or Edit/Toggle comment

Expected: lines 1 & 2 commented out with # at start of each line (as these lines only, are highlighted)

Actual: lines 1, 2 & 3 commented out with # at start of each line

IMO this can create an unwanted comment-out line of code, often going unnoticed.

Note: if lines 1 & 2 are partially selected, then only lines 1 & 2 are commented-out.

I suggest my "expected" behaviour above, should be the actual, as per other code editors with a similar feature.

data.title: Add negate method to Vector2 and Vector3
data.body:
Added negate method to Vector2 and Vector3 and filled out the classes.xml

The negate method returns a vector with the same magnitude, but in the opposite direction.

data.title: Port demos to TSCN/TRES formats
data.body: The demos are currently using the binary SCN format. Now that TSCN is relatively mature, I think we should switch all demos to it, so that it's easier to spot bugs or regressions in scene files (such as e.g. 4eb49cc).

data.title: Sound error when moving the camera
data.body:
Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.1

When the camera moves in _some specific ways_, an error occurs in the console:

```
ERROR: update: Invalid mix rate for voice (0) check for invalid pitch_scale param.
   At: servers/spatial_sound_2d/spatial_sound_2d_server_sw.cpp:1003
```

Then the voice that was playing cannot be controlled or stopped by code, and seems to loop forever if it was set to loop.

It happens often and randomly in my game and confuses sound feedbacks, so it took me hours to figure out how to reproduce this clearly in a minimal project:
http://zylannprods.fr/dl/godot/AudioError.zip
Just play the scene. A looping sound will play, then click to see the error happen.

data.title: Now the timer could be paused
data.body:
Hey I implemented pause behaviour for the timer, is the same methods and behaviour from animation player adapted to timer class.
You could resume/pause the timer with:
timer.set_active(true/false)
and for test if timer is paused:
timer.is_active()

Here is a patch.diff with the changes from this pull if your prefer that
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/lked9nru3ac3za8/timerpause.zip?dl=0

This fix: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/4175

data.title: Added insert mode to text editor
data.body: Added insert mode to the text editor when the insert key is pressed.

data.title: Allow to disable the "output overflow" limit
data.body: Implement an option to disable the "output overflow" limit.

data.title: Progress bar minsize now checks percent_visible
data.body: Allows for really thin progress bars such as for pixel-art styles (e.g. 2 pixels high).

data.title: XCode not launching project:  returned: ERR_OUT_OF_MEMORY [0;31m   At: core/vector.h:283.[0m (lldb)
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
XCode 7,   OS X 10.11.1 
iPad Air 1 (iOS 9.2.1)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When running the template provided in "Export templates" application always crashes on launch.
It doesnt matter if you use empty data.pck or import your own.
Also it doesnt matter what iOS version is on the device, tried on iPhone 5s (iOS 8.2) and iPhone 6 Plus (iOS 9.3)

**Steps to reproduce:**
- download the ios export template from godotengine.org
- open the project in xcode
- connect device
- click run
- and it crashes right after being deployed on device

data.title: Godot architecture diagram
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I was trying to find what input library Godot uses, to look what features does it exhibit and if there are any metrics like latency etc. gathered for it. So I went to https://github.com/godotengine/godot/tree/master/drivers and couldn't understand what most of those directories contain.

Here is the list:

```
alsa               - audio
angle              - graphics
builtin_openssl2   - network
builtin_zlib       - utility/compression
chibi              - ???
convex_decomp      - ???
dds                 
etc1
gl_context
gles2             
jpegd
mpc
nedmalloc
nrex
ogg
openssl           - network
opus
png
pnm
pulseaudio
pvr
rtaudio
speex
squish
theora             - utilities/formats
unix
vorbis             - utilities/formats
webp               - utilities/formats
webpold
windows
```

Above I tried to map few logical blocks to show what information I expect to find about them. As you may see I couldn't find the module that is responsible for input (like http://gainput.johanneskuhlmann.de/). Perhaps it is managed by Godot core directly, but I have no proof and not enough hours to read the code to figure this out.

What would help is a colored diagram of components of Godot engine (even a list of blocks would find for the first approximation) - every color is a function of the component as shown above. Then a picture of how different functions are meld together, and which components are responsible for every function (color).

I could do some ugly SVG's in Inkscape that could be improved later, but it would be nice to learn something from design/art gurus and get something inspiring as a result.

data.title: Cannot import stereo sound
data.body:
Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.1

I am trying to add a stereo looping sound FX in my game, which I can play already (it was auto-imported), but cannot loop.
After some research I found out it needs to be re-imported so I can check the "loop" option.
So I re-imported the sound: in the dialog, I didn't ticked "mono" because I want it to be stereo, then Ok.
![Import dialog](http://zylannprods.fr/dl/godot/StereoSoundImport/screen1.png)
This created another file .smp, however it is mono...
![File browser](http://zylannprods.fr/dl/godot/StereoSoundImport/screen2.png)
Side note: shouldn't the 'loop' property better be a parameter of the sample player?

data.title: Reimporting a 3D scene doesn't update meshes
data.body:
Godot 2.0.1 under GNU/Linux and Windows 8 (tried on both, same results).

If I re-export a scene from Blender using the better collada exporter, Godot shows the red exclamation mark sear the "Settings" menu. I can click it, the list of asssets to re-import displays. I click ok, the re-importing seems to progress fine. All is done, but the geometry never changes. Textures can be re-imported and they update, but meshes never update. I need to delete the scene and start over if I want to change something.

data.title: Documentation version
data.body:
Two additional files could be useful in doc/base :  
- A file with just the documentation's version (or engine major version + minor version/build) for avoid to load and parse the entire file.
- A second file with the conventions and structure used (recently the codeblock tag has been added)

data.title: Option to toggle line numbers.
data.body: Added an option to toggle drawing line numbers in the text editor.

data.title: Implement scaling up/down of the text inside the script editor.
data.body: Add an option to scale the text size inside the script editor so that making tutorials will be better.

data.title: Have Editor Remember Visible Collision Shapes Setting
data.body:
The Visual Collision Shapes setting is great, especially for us programmer types. No longer do I have to come up with placeholder art, especially early on in development when I'm trying to get the core of the engine down.

But every time I re-open the editor, I invariably forget that Visible Collision Shapes always defaults to Off, so I'm always confused oh-so-briefly that nothing appears on the screen.

It'd be nice if the editor remembered the state of Visible Collision Shapes (either per-editor or per-project), as I suspect I'm not the only one who uses it as a significant source of visual information during development.

This behavior should probably also apply to the other editor/debug settings, but I haven't used them yet.

data.title: GUI framework
data.body: How about using a gui framework like [electron,](http://electron.atom.io/) for the editor. I think most of the godot usability problems are related to the editor ui, and the editor has problems with the ui because of its implementation using a custom ui framework, the godot gui framework is well suited for a game (uis in games are very simple or should be) but not for a complex application like an editor, using html, and css would be very beneficial for future editor modifications.

data.title: Math operation on editor
data.body:
Hi. This is a suggestion to speed up the work flow in Godot. The idea is to have the ability of type math operation on the properties that are shown on the editor, such as Pos, Rot, Scale... e.g. 70+190, 70*(2+24). I know it might sound kind of silly but most of the time with need to set a specific value that is the two time another one or when duplicate a sprite increase the Pos.x by the width or... you got the idea.

Not having to switch to the calculator will be awesome!

data.title: inherit PKG_CONFIG_PATH from environment
data.body:
Allows pkg-config to read files from custom install directories during build.

This addresses issue #4161

data.title: Buttons with get_drag_data not styled properly
data.body:
Godot 2.0.1-stable Win 10 64bit

Buttons that overload get_drag_data() and return a non falsey value don't change the texture properly when the drag finishes (active texture is left instead of the normal one)

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a new scene with a CanvasLayer main node. Set it's scale to 3,3 for better visibility.
- Add a GridContainer
- Add a Button element, set it's text to anything eg. `some text here`, create a new script and attach it
- Insert some code that uses get_drag_data() eg.

```
    func get_drag_data(pos): return true
    func can_drop_data(pos,data): return true
    func drop_data(pos,data): pass
```
- Duplicate the button a few times
- Start the scene
- Click and drag a button to any other button. The original button's texture stays "active" instead of returning to "normal".
- On a bugged button (with "active" texture), click to revert to "normal" texture. Note that hovering with TAB and using SPACE does not work.

It seems to not be bugged without get_drag_data(). To check this:
1. Edit any of the button's script
2. Comment the get_drag_data(pos) line
3. Run the scene

**Minimal project**
[drag_bugtest.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/195582/drag_bugtest.zip)
